 From the Code of Virginia:
 
 "Firearm" means any weapon that will or is designed to or may readily be converted to expel single or multiple projectiles by the action of an explosion of a combustible material; or the frame or receiver of any such weapon.
 Virginia Code § 18.2-433.1

 Go ahead if you like, but the ONLY part of the gun considered a firearm is the reciever, and specifically in weapons with an upper and lower reciever, whichever part carries the bolt. The trigger has nothing to do with it. This is why you can purchae trigger assembelies mail order or online without needing an FFL. 
 
 For the purposes of the NFA, there are some registered bolts out there. In the case of a registerd FA bolt, the bolt is considered the firearm. This occured becuase when the ban on new machine gun productrion was passed (reagan era), manufaturers rushed to register anything and everythin ghtta they could. They stripped bolts out of finished weeapons, stamped them with individual serial numbers, and registered them as machine guns. They did this with a number of Dias devices, too (a dias is simply a little piece of sheetmetal that goes in an AR-15).
The serial numbered part is the gun: receivers for most rifles, frames for most pistols. Trigger groups are also considered expendable parts.

 Don't kid yourself, this is from the BATFE website and while not actively enforced due to the impossibility of monitoring all individuals, they have it to use at will and (last sentence) it covers every possible loophole:
 
 ~No person shall make a firearm unless he has (a) filed with the Secretary a written application, in duplicate, to make and register the firearm on the form prescribed by the Secretary;(b) paid any tax payable on the making and such payment is evidenced by the proper stamp affixed to the original application form;(c) identified the firearm to be made in the application form in such manner as the Secretary may by regulations prescribe;(d) identified himself in the application form in such manner as the Secretary may by regulations prescribe, except that, if such person is an individual, the identification must include his fingerprints and his photograph;and (e) obtained the approval of the Secretary to make and register the firearm and the application form shows such approval.Applications shall be denied if the making or possession of the firearm would place the person making the firearm in violation of law.~
 
 That doesn't include machine guns, including individual manufacture, which are prohibited unless the sear and/or receiver were registered prior to 7/86. We have approximately 220,000 legal machine guns in the US (transferable to an individual) and that's it.  What you posted above are requirements fro an NFA weapon. From the ATF web page:
 
 
(A7) Does the GCA prohibit anyone from making a handgun, shotgun or rifle?
 
 
 
 With certain exceptions a firearm may be made by a nonlicensee provided it is not for sale and the maker is not prohibited from possessing firearms. However, a person is prohibited from making a semiautomatic assault weapon or assembling a nonsporting semiautomatic rifle or nonsporting shotgun from imported parts. In addition, the making of an NFA firearm requires a tax payment and approval by ATF. An application to make a machinegun will not be approved unless documentation is submitted showing that the firearm is being made for a federal or state agency. [18 U. S. C. 922( o), (r), (v), and 923, 27 CFR 178.39, 178.40, 178.41 and 179.105]

 I was in colorado once visiting a friend, and we went out into the country to do a little shooting. I was shooting a pistol I had built at home (1911 widebody w/ damascus slide chambered in 7.62x25). A cop pulled up while we were shooting ansd was talking to us. He asked to see my pistol. I handed it to him and he looked at it and asked "who made this". I told him "I did". He immediatly went into his percieved legality regarding the construction of a homebuilt firearm, the necessity of putting serial numbers on them (I don't put serial number on anything I build), and the licensisng requirements for being a firearms manufaturer. 
 
 He called for backup and put me in cuffs. I could not convince him to just open the glovebox and take a look at the ATF letter there. It was not until there were 5 or 6 more cops on the scene, and they were tearuing my truck apart, that one of them opened the glovebox and found the envelope that contained my letter from the ATF (which I had thoughtfully labeled "Letter from ATF concerning homebuilt firearms and marking requirements". 4 minutes later I was out of cuffs, and a local sheriffs deputy was apologising profusely.
 
 Moral of story, GET YOUR LETTER AND CARRY IT WITH YOU.
